The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" and the "Anti-counterfeiting Amendments Act of 2004" prohibit trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The act specifies penalties for knowingly trafficking in counterfeit labels, documentation, or packaging related to various types of works, with fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. The term 'illicit label' is defined as a genuine certificate or similar labeling component used by the copyright owner to verify the authenticity of various types of works without authorization. The term 'documentation or packaging' refers to physical documentation or packaging for phonorecords, computer programs, motion pictures, or other audiovisual works. The term 'counterfeit documentation or packaging' refers to fake packaging that appears genuine but is not. Subsection (c) outlines that counterfeit labels or illicit labels are affixed to various copyrighted works like sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual art. The amendment adds provisions for civil remedies for copyright owners affected by violations of counterfeit labels on various copyrighted works. The amendment allows individuals threatened with injury by copyright violations to bring a civil action in court. The court has the discretion to grant injunctions, impound infringing articles, and award attorney fees, costs, actual damages, and profits to the injured party. The injured party is entitled to recover actual damages and profits from the violator for copyright violations. The court calculates actual damages based on the value of infringing items and the number of items involved. The value of copyrighted items for determining damages in copyright violations is based on the retail value of authorized copies of the items, such as sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, and literary works. The Copyright Act allows for statutory damages ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 for each violation of copyright infringement. The court may triple the damages for subsequent violations within 3 years of a previous judgment. The Copyright Act allows for triple damages if a person violates copyright infringement within 3 years of a previous judgment. A civil action must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the violation. The table of sections for chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit labels, or counterfeit documentation or packaging. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability under certain sections of Title 17, United States Code, or the fair use under section 107 of Title 17, United States Code. The amendments also do not apply to electronic transmissions of specific documents under Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect fair use under section 107 of Title 17, United States Code, for certain documents described in Title 18, United States Code. SEC. 201. This title is known as the Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act. SEC. 202. Amendment to Trademark Act of 1946 includes a new subsection that presumes willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name. SEC. 203. Amendment to Title 17, United States Code. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement in cases where false contact information is knowingly provided to a domain name registrar. This does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as per the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of falsely registering a domain name and using it in the commission of a felony offense. The maximum imprisonment for the offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less. The terms "falsely registers" and "domain name" are defined within the section. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines to ensure harsh penalties for felony offenses committed online using a domain name with false contact information. Sentencing enhancements will be provided for those who knowingly provide false contact information to domain name authorities. Anyone convicted of a felony offense involving providing false contact information to domain name authorities will face harsh penalties. The term "domain name" is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 205. CONSTRUCTION. This title does not affect free speech or press rights related to domain name activities. Courts have discretion in determining damages for intellectual property infringement and terms of imprisonment. TITLE III--COURTS. Additional court locations are added in Colorado and Northern District of New York. SEC. 302 amends Section 112(a) of title 28, United States Code by adding "Plattsburgh" as a place of holding court in the Northern District of New York.
